content: I forgot to mention this yesterday, but I will need to leave early from the meeting today.
Hey @WG-governance =)
hey
:wave:
We’re having a meeting? I seem to have lost the event in my calendar.
Hmm.
It's in mine :)
(and you're invited to it)
I've got in on mine too
must be gremlins in the calendar
Okay, well welcome to meeting everyone! I believe we wanted to continue to the discussion on working groups and @nikomatsakis you posted a proposal earlier this week I believe.
it's true, I did
here

nikomatsakis said:

I've been thinking about it. It seems to me that there is perpetual confusion about the idea of working groups vs project groups etc. I'm not sure how truly harmful this is but I was thinking about an alternative. Given that we have a notion of "subteams" already (e.g., the dev-tools team has various subteams, etc), maybe we should simplify to:

  • project groups -- execute a defined, often cross-cutting, project with relatively well-defined scope (e.g., project-ffi-unwind)
  • teams and subteams -- indefinite entities that exist to tend to a given area, codebase, etc
Part of this would be trying to make the embedded wg an official team.
I’m all in favour of this

I'm basically wondering if we can draw a fairly clear line -- I worry that having too many categories is too complex. It seems clear that teams aren't always permanent (e.g., docs team...), and we have a hierarchical team structure, so it seems like we can have teams for domains that we think are worth it.
But by the same token I think it puts a suitable "barrier" to creating a team, and the idea of listing community groups or something might be a good "entry level".
sounds good to me
I think one question mark is what happens to the other existing domain working groups
bingo
In particular, the ones that aren't strongly associated with a team
I'm thinking of CLI and secure-code
I'm not sure if there exist more?
Yeah I was about to ask which are even still active.
There was one "networking", or "wg-async-foundations", but I think it can become essentially a project group.
I think we could define a kind of goal for that
So, those are two cases in the fuzzy place between project and not?
I don't feel either CLI or secure-code is really "project" oriented
are they active? could a parent be found to adopt them?
well there is certainly activity in #wg-secure-code
I would say secure code is largely a libs issue
I tend to agree with that
based on how they operate
Yeah, and I think it'd be plausible to make them a kind of secure code subteam
one thing I will say is that, in the past, we had this idea that domain wgs were that way because they didn't have decision making power
but then, the embedded wg has an rfc process
it seems to me more that the question is not about "making decisions" but more like "the scope of those decisions"

If we're all in agreement on the proposal (which I believe we are), I think we should reach out to the wg leads and ask them if they would want to stay in project. I've had off-hand conversations where some of the leads have said they are unsure how much they benefit from being part of the project.
I am wondering if the proposal is complete without this community group concept
also I think I should try to write it up :)
but I agree with the idea of scheduling some time to talk closely with the existing groups
I would frame it more as "here is a working proposal and we'd like to see how you feel and would fit into that"
Ok, so the proposed types of groups in the Rust project would be: teams, project groups parented by those teams. Outside of Rust would be community groups. Is this correct?
Domain groups would go away?
yeah, I think that those are just teams focused on a domain
or else maybe not part of rust org officially
i.e., a community group that we list

So, there are teams and community groups, and some of those relate to domains. But there is no such thing as a domain group, in that picture. There are teams that work on domain-related stuff, and community groups that work on domain-related stuff. yes?
correct
And there would be a formal difference between "team" and "subteam"?
(that would be confusing : D )
We already have a notion of "subteams", it's really just teams that "refine" part of the scope of their parent
e.g. there is the dev-tools team and within there is clippy team
similarly within community team there is events team
I imagine that within compiler team there would be prioritization team
(what we now call #t-compiler/wg-prioritization)
so they are teams, they are just parented teams
perhaps also subteams for specific areas, like the "type checker team" or whatever, per https://github.com/rust-lang/compiler-team/issues/288
Well I think the only difference between "team" and "subteam" is their relationship in the structure. What would be the difference between a "sub-team" and a "project group" be?
Subteams don't have a defined goal
they cover an area but aren't trying to complete a "project"
But they don't need a separate definition, right?

project groups have a charter to complete a specific project; I think they would typically also not have final decision making power, i.e., they are preparing a design (or menu of designs) for lang team
yes, this is clear in the recent document XAMPPRocky wrote
I think having the distinction of "a project group is a group focused on a particular project" is reasonable and useful, beacuse e.g. it'd be good to list all project groups on a separate page
as a way to get involved in the project
but also like a unit of planning
That makes sense to me. So what are the steps here to make this change?
(my expectation for the lang team is that we we try to encapsulate as much as possible our activities within active projects)
I think writing the proposal in somewhat more detail and then approaching the existing working grousp and trying to fit them in
I specifically put "working groups" and not just domain because we have various wgs that I think would be "reclassified" as subteams in this proposal (e.g., triage wg of the release team)
but I think that's ok

(similar, I think that e.g. the "windows group" or "ARM group" for the compiler team ought to be subteams eventually, right now they are just notification groups where we ping people -- is that distinction worth bringing into this?)
...it's kind of an orthogonal thing but if we're trying to define the overall taxonomy of Rust governance structure...
basically we have some groups in the compiler team (cleanup crew, windows group, etc) that people can just sign up for on their own, and then they get pinged
I think we could mention it but we don't have to be strict about the structure of those groups.
it's not really a "group" in the same sense
But those are still teams, yes? parented teams
Like something like "There are also groups of volunteers from the community who offer their time and advice to the Rust team".

one thing I've considered is that teams/groups could have 4 categories of people associated with them:

  • leads
  • members
  • notification.. people
  • alumni (former members)

with leads and members being nominated for effort, and notification is a way that people can sign up to get pinged and aren't really "members" in the same sense.
but now that I write it out I wonder if it's just too much complexity and it's better to just have "we also have lists you can sign up for", I don't know.
I'm inclined to leave them as distinct things for now and consider merging at some point in the future, I think

( XAMPPRocky said:

Like something like "There are also groups of volunteers from the community who offer their time and advice to the Rust team".

ok, so these are community groups then. )

nikomatsakis said:

I'm inclined to leave them as distinct things for now and consider merging at some point in the future, I think

I think this the right move. Right now we don't have much of a need to have this for more teams.
ok let me take some quick notes somewhere...here is a hackmd
wait which are distinct things for now?
side note that Santiago Pastorino and I have been talking about how we should really try to find some setup to assure a bit more security for hackmd and the like
This all mostly makes sense to me
i.e., to ensure that some random prankster doesn't scrape zulip-archive.rust-lang.org and insert offensive comments in there
...but i'm going to worry about that later :)
(idea we kicked around: a zulip bot where you can ping it and it will scrape the hackmd URL, find the people who are involved in the current topic, and restrict edits to those people)
no idea how easy/hard that would be to do though :)

nikomatsakis said:

i.e., to ensure that some random prankster doesn't scrape zulip-archive.rust-lang.org and insert offensive comments in there

Yeah I think it would make sense at some point to try to do an audit of our infrastructure, but that's for another time.
OK, I think that lays out roughly what I am proposing
I don't love the name "community group" but don't have a better one.
I guess it's fine, it just uses the term "group" again ;)
well, if the term group is only used for community group, then it is consistent (: Unless you say a team is a group of people, which case its grammatical and not a label so much. (;
I mean the term group is pretty generic I guess :)
I was just wary of having another term like "working group' that everybody uses to mean everything
that's the danger of it, yes
and that is why you define things (: So. Mostly this meeting is writing that HackMD, so shall the minutes point to that?
Or I can summarize
pointing to it seems ok
Hi @XAMPPRocky --
so I think part of this community groups idea would be finding some way to list them on the web page
some concerns would be (1) the list gets outdated quickly maybe
(2) it's kind of unfunded mandate on "some team" to kind of look after this list and vet things etc
I imagine there'd be some minimal criteria (probably "must have CoC"), maybe?
Some regular check-in process?
mmm seems unlikely to really happen
I wonder though if we could
e.g. if you have a discourse instance, or a github org
if there's some simple way to get like "is there still activity?"
programatically
Or basically, check in once every six months and if there is radio silence, the community group is removed from the list : D
just so we can show a badge next to it
Yeah I think I'm more concerned with 2 than 1. Anecdotally I've heard some groups in the community aren't as welcoming and inclusive as ourselves.
kind of like the archiving
yeah I am a bit wary of having to make judgements
indeed I'm wary enough that I'm tempted to nix the idea
Well, "has a CoC" and "makes contact every six months" is pretty judgement free
right, I guess so long as it's like this, I imagine that at some point we'll get e.g. moderation complaints against a group
otoh it does seem useful to be able to say like "we're forming a mail handling group and we'd like to list it"
@nikomatsakis This feels like something that would be appropriate to contribute to the rust wiki or some other community resource where there's less chance that it can be seen as an endorsement.
there isn't a rust wiki, but yes
partially for related reasons =)
In what official space could something be listed and not sound like an endorsement?
but I agree that having some other resource we can point at might be nice...
There is, I mean the community wiki.
ok, I see
https://runrust.miraheze.org/wiki/Main_Page
in that case I could remove it from the list
since that's not really associated with rust org
narrowing scope always seems good to me ..
So we used to list meetup groups on the website
I feel similarly about community groups
list them in a place, not much fanfare, wth a disclaimer
this is roughly what I had in mind
well https://community.mozilla.org/groups/
community groups can be created here, if folks like
I feel like many groups will be focused on a project
and the community team would deal with the "are they inactive or doing nasty things" problem. So if folks want to get involved
ok
I guess my canonical example is something like "various people working on mail-handling software"
or for that matter perhaps the CLI group
Mail handling software isn't something with a beginning and an end . . .
anyway I can go either way, I think a low-key reference on the web-page is fine, but it will imply some maintenance costs
I feel like my concern with community groups is having to try to define a level of work for the group.

Val Grimm said:

Mail handling software isn't something with a beginning and an end . . .

lol, I meant "community groups" -- I guess the vague term "group" being used twice is already causing confusion :)
I think we should have no definition?
well, or encourage folks to go to the https://community.mozilla.org/groups/ and create groups there and the Rust Project can just say "hey, there may be some Rust groups here"
and the groups are community groupos
like, we're just saying that if you want to list your name with some link, right? not that we did any "vetting" per se
Project teams
Community Groups
Right, but at the same time it shouldn't be a place for people to post any open source organization that has a rust project right?
I guess I think that'd be ok
maybe so diluted as to be useless ten
Like to be specific I would be concerned about hosting blockchain group projects.
So, the kind of community groups you're talking about would totally fit in the Community Portal . . . and then it wouldn't be the Rust Project's problem. Community has moderation folks for this.
Community Portal as in: https://community.mozilla.org/groups/
And community groups wouldn't be hosted by the Rust Project
the term "host" feels a bit misleading
As in not on the Github
perhaps you just mean "list"?
listed or on the Github
Just a pointer to the community site
Does this sound right?
Yeah I just meant as in having a link somewhere.
I'm not sure what "this" refers to in that sentence. you mean giving references to some places where rust communities may be listed, @Val Grimm?
I guess I think that linking to e.g. mozilla community site or rust wiki is fine and harmless, but kind of orthogonal
I'm not sure hwo many Rust groups would put themselves on the mozilla page
but I also kind of think this isn't that big a deal
and that people can self-organize and post periodic reminders to users etc
without us really doing anything
@nikomatsakis Honestly I would prefer that approach of being one stepped removed. Giving people links to lists.
Ok, so basically, the Rust Project wouldn't list or link to any community groups, or keep community projects on its Github.
Have I got this right?
Or is there a link to email lists?
yes I think that's right

And maybe suggest to Community Groups that if they want folks to find them they can create a group on the Mozilla Community Portal, which the Rust Project will link to instead of any individual groups?
That's their choice, but then if they want to be more visible they can be
I think that would be the right way to go.
OK. Let's remove community groups and edit hackmd?
I have to run now
but I think the next steps are to look at existing groups and describe how they fit into this taxonomy
Oh right, thanks everyone for attending!
